thread.title: Governor Inslee to unveil final budget amid criticism over state spending habits
thread.title_full: Governor Inslee to unveil final budget amid criticism over state spending habits

author: KOMO News Staff
title: Governor Inslee to unveil final budget amid criticism over state spending habits
text: {p}{ }Flag for usage of AI Transcript Assistant{/p}{p}{ } Proof of concept AI assistant.{/p}{p}Gov. Jay Inslee is set to unveil his final budget Tuesday following a spending freeze imposed on state agencies amid a projected revenue shortfall.{/p}{p}The spending freeze, {a href=\"https://komonews.com/news/local/governor-inslee-imposes-washington-state-government-spending-freeze-amid-projected-revenue-shortfall\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://komonews.com/news/local/governor-inslee-imposes-washington-state-government-spending-freeze-amid-projected-revenue-shortfall\"}announced earlier this month{/a}, was a response to a forecasted $400 million revenue shortfall through 2029. Inslee is legally required to propose a balanced budget over four years.{/p}{p}{sd-embed class=\"sd-embedded-media\" data-embed-file=\"%3Cdiv%3E%3Cscript%3Ewindow.tagboardDomain%20=%20%22https://embed.tagboard.com%22;%3C/script%3E%3Cdiv%20class=%22tagboard-embed%22%20tgb-embed-id=%2214825%22%3E%3C/div%3E%3Cscript%20src=%22https://embed.tagboard.com/embed/assets/js/embed.js%22%3E%3C/script%3E%3C/div%3E\" data-embed-type=\"code\" contenteditable=\"false\"}{/sd-embed}{/p}{p}The Office of Financial Management has reported a $10-$12 billion operating budget deficit over the next four years, with revenues not meeting previous forecasts. However, the same research indicates that revenue is expected to rise by approximately $5 billion in each of the next two bienniums.{/p}{p}Republicans have criticized the spending habits of state Democrats, arguing that the increase in revenue should suffice without additional taxes. {/p}{p}\"We got drunk on spending during the pandemic and after, and we made a lot of reckless decisions that have increased our budgets,\" Rpresentative Chris Corry, a Republican from Yakima, said.{/p}{p}Inslee had previously approved a $2 billion budget increase for education, mental health, and housing services earlier this year. The spending freeze affects non-essential hiring, service contracts, purchasing, and travel, but exempts spending on critical services and hiring for critical vacancies.{/p}{p}State Republicans have expressed concerns about potential tax increases to meet the spending goals of the Democrat-controlled state government. {/p}{p}The new budget will be revealed at 11:15 a.m.{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning be alert for strong wind gusts along the coast and north interior, heavy rain through the day Tuesday bringing possible river flooding, and snowy, icy roads through the Cascade passes and eastern Washington.{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}Rain will increase mid-morning and persist through the day. An atmospheric river accompanies the slow-moving frontal system. Snow levels will rise in the mountains and rain is going to be heavy at times in addition to a round of gusty wind.{/p}{p}Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning be alert for strong wind gusts along the coast and north interior, heavy rain through Tuesday bringing possible river flooding, and snowy, icy roads through the Cascade passes and eastern Washington.{/p}{p}Monday evening rain showers will return to south Washington and slide over Olympia to Seattle and Issaquah closer to 10 pm. Most of the rain will stay south of Everett tonight and diminish in the early hours of Tuesday morning.{/p}{p}Tuesday temperatures during all the rain will begin in the mid to upper 30s and warm to the upper 40s and lower 50s.{/p}{p}Rain will increase mid-morning and persist through the day. An atmospheric river accompanies the slow-moving frontal system. Snow levels will rise in the mountains and rain is going to be heavy at times in addition to a round of gusty wind.{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}The heaviest rain over the coast, Olympic Peninsula, and North Cascades will cause all of us to closely watch the rivers flowing off the mountains. Expect rivers, streams and creeks to rise quickly. There is a flood watch on the Skokomish River in Mason County.{/p}{p}Dangerous, slippery travel on roads across the Cascades and eastern Washington begins tonight and lasts through early Wednesday. In addition to several inches of snow above 3,000 feet there will also be varying amounts of icing from freezing rain.{/p}{p}Overnight into Tuesday the ice and snow begins over Easton through Ellensburg, including surrounding towns of Roslyn, Thorp, and Yakima. From 4 a.m. Tuesday through 4 a.m. Wednesday a Winter Weather Advisory will include the danger of snow and freezing rain with ice accumulations developing across all mountain passes and a greater area of eastern and central Washington. Be aware it will be a dangerous time to drive on roads through these spots due to ice.{/p}{p}Snoqualmie Pass will likely develop the slick, icy conditions between approximately 4 to 5 p.m Tuesday late afternoon and evening. Enough warming to all rain should occur by early Wednesday.{/p}{p}Wind will increase Tuesday afternoon, coming from the south, with the strongest wind at the coast and northwest interior. Wind gusts for these areas will range from 50-60 mph for the south coast, for the central and north coast up to 55 mph, the northern inland waters the wind gusts will 35-45mph. For inland cities around Puget Sound, wind gusts will increase early evening from 25-35 mph.{/p}{p}Wind will ease Wednesday, showers will decrease with much of Wednesday becoming dry and partly to mostly cloudy.{/p}{p}Meteorologist Rebecca Stevenson{br}The KOMO 4 Forecast Team{/p}{p}{strong}Updated Monday Night{/strong}{/p}{p}{ }Flag for usage of AI Transcript Assistant{/p}{p}{ } Proof of concept AI assistant.{/p}{p}Gov. Jay Inslee is set to unveil his final budget Tuesday following a spending freeze imposed on state agencies amid a projected revenue shortfall.{/p}{p}The spending freeze, {a href=\"https://komonews.com/news/local/governor-inslee-imposes-washington-state-government-spending-freeze-amid-projected-revenue-shortfall\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://komonews.com/news/local/governor-inslee-imposes-washington-state-government-spending-freeze-amid-projected-revenue-shortfall\"}announced earlier this month{/a}, was a response to a forecasted $400 million revenue shortfall through 2029. Inslee is legally required to propose a balanced budget over four years.{/p}{p}{sd-embed class=\"sd-embedded-media\" data-embed-file=\"%3Cdiv%3E%3Cscript%3Ewindow.tagboardDomain%20=%20%22https://embed.tagboard.com%22;%3C/script%3E%3Cdiv%20class=%22tagboard-embed%22%20tgb-embed-id=%2214825%22%3E%3C/div%3E%3Cscript%20src=%22https://embed.tagboard.com/embed/assets/js/embed.js%22%3E%3C/script%3E%3C/div%3E\" data-embed-type=\"code\" contenteditable=\"false\"}{/sd-embed}{/p}{p}The Office of Financial Management has reported a $10-$12 billion operating budget deficit over the next four years, with revenues not meeting previous forecasts. However, the same research indicates that revenue is expected to rise by approximately $5 billion in each of the next two bienniums.{/p}{p}Republicans have criticized the spending habits of state Democrats, arguing that the increase in revenue should suffice without additional taxes. {/p}{p}\"We got drunk on spending during the pandemic and after, and we made a lot of reckless decisions that have increased our budgets,\" Rpresentative Chris Corry, a Republican from Yakima, said.{/p}{p}Inslee had previously approved a $2 billion budget increase for education, mental health, and housing services earlier this year. The spending freeze affects non-essential hiring, service contracts, purchasing, and travel, but exempts spending on critical services and hiring for critical vacancies.{/p}{p}State Republicans have expressed concerns about potential tax increases to meet the spending goals of the Democrat-controlled state government. {/p}{p}The new budget will be revealed at 11:15 a.m.{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning be alert for strong wind gusts along the coast and north interior, heavy rain through the day Tuesday bringing possible river flooding, and snowy, icy roads through the Cascade passes and eastern Washington.{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}Rain will increase mid-morning and persist through the day. An atmospheric river accompanies the slow-moving frontal system. Snow levels will rise in the mountains and rain is going to be heavy at times in addition to a round of gusty wind.{/p}{p}Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning be alert for strong wind gusts along the coast and north interior, heavy rain through Tuesday bringing possible river flooding, and snowy, icy roads through the Cascade passes and eastern Washington.{/p}{p}Monday evening rain showers will return to south Washington and slide over Olympia to Seattle and Issaquah closer to 10 pm. Most of the rain will stay south of Everett tonight and diminish in the early hours of Tuesday morning.{/p}{p}Tuesday temperatures during all the rain will begin in the mid to upper 30s and warm to the upper 40s and lower 50s.{/p}{p}Rain will increase mid-morning and persist through the day. An atmospheric river accompanies the slow-moving frontal system. Snow levels will rise in the mountains and rain is going to be heavy at times in addition to a round of gusty wind.{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}The heaviest rain over the coast, Olympic Peninsula, and North Cascades will cause all of us to closely watch the rivers flowing off the mountains. Expect rivers, streams and creeks to rise quickly. There is a flood watch on the Skokomish River in Mason County.{/p}{p}Dangerous, slippery travel on roads across the Cascades and eastern Washington begins tonight and lasts through early Wednesday. In addition to several inches of snow above 3,000 feet there will also be varying amounts of icing from freezing rain.{/p}{p}Overnight into Tuesday the ice and snow begins over Easton through Ellensburg, including surrounding towns of Roslyn, Thorp, and Yakima. From 4 a.m. Tuesday through 4 a.m. Wednesday a Winter Weather Advisory will include the danger of snow and freezing rain with ice accumulations developing across all mountain passes and a greater area of eastern and central Washington. Be aware it will be a dangerous time to drive on roads through these spots due to ice.{/p}{p}Snoqualmie Pass will likely develop the slick, icy conditions between approximately 4 to 5 p.m Tuesday late afternoon and evening. Enough warming to all rain should occur by early Wednesday.{/p}{p}Wind will increase Tuesday afternoon, coming from the south, with the strongest wind at the coast and northwest interior. Wind gusts for these areas will range from 50-60 mph for the south coast, for the central and north coast up to 55 mph, the northern inland waters the wind gusts will 35-45mph. For inland cities around Puget Sound, wind gusts will increase early evening from 25-35 mph.{/p}{p}Wind will ease Wednesday, showers will decrease with much of Wednesday becoming dry and partly to mostly cloudy.{/p}{p}Meteorologist Rebecca Stevenson{br}The KOMO 4 Forecast Team{/p}{p}{strong}Updated Monday Night{/strong}{/p}
